article.title: Pioneering voice and conversational AI platform boosts business productivity
article.teaser: Conversational artificial iintelligence (AI) such as chatbots, messaging apps and virtual assistants still has a way to go before enhancing user experience, creating operational efficiencies and reducing costs. An EU initiative developed Europe’s first voice and conversational AI platform to speed up this process.

section.sectionBody:
Today, most IT vendors don’t have their own voice technology, and this creates cost, pricing and multi-vendor integration issues. The majority of bot services and platforms are highly scripted with little to no natural language processing (NLP) or AI. They aren’t contextually aware.
Most platforms aren’t very customisable or they require significant custom programming and professional services by vendors. This limits their extensibility. Complex conversational assistants demand significant ongoing NLP training. Most bot services don’t have an easy way to continuously improve NLP. Large cloud-based platforms like Amazon and Google require all user data to go through a central cloud framework, resulting in privacy and data security challenges and risks.
Thanks to the EU-funded OmniBot project, “we’ve introduced Europe to the first-ever voice and conversational AI platform based on proprietary IP enabling businesses to create, customise and integrate advanced conversational chat and voice assistants while maintaining complete control of their data, brands and users,” says project coordinator Jascha Stein, CEO of the eponymous company. The innovation “promises to automate business processes, drive productivity and improve customer experience.”
Maximising organisational resources
The ecosystem platform supports text, voice, telephony and other communication channels. For companies and original equipment manufacturers, OmniBot “provides an attractive and affordable ownership alternative to current market players,” he notes. “They can build, integrate and manage a complete bot framework one time and then leverage the same framework across many other use cases and communication channels, saving companies considerable time and costs.” The OmniBot platform is designed for large collaborative teams and has many features to help manage and control projects and project teams. It also provides tools for business and IT professionals to plan, design, test and manage bots across company-wide conversational AI applications.
OmniBot is one of the most customisable platforms in the industry, and includes application programming interfaces, a software development kit and programing tools optimised for advanced customisation and automation. This allows simple bot dialogues to drive complex client interactions. The bots are built with custom or predefined bot modules. Each bot typically has multiple modules that can also be reused.
“The OmniBot solution advances the state of the art in AI technologies,” Stein adds, and facilitates building conversational interfaces into any chatbot or virtual assistant application that uses voice and text. Advanced chatbots and voice-enabled virtual assistants are easily trained. Every bot comes with human-supervised, machine live-learning capabilities, ensuring that the bot learns and improves its contextual understanding very quickly. “This human-in-the-loop machine learning functionality represents an important state-of-the-art innovation.”
In contrast to most other solutions, OmniBot bot dialogues are designed through a graphical editor with drag and drop functionality. The dialogues are well structured and easily readable, allowing for an easier path to the addition of more complexity while improving reliability and extensibility.
“OmniBot is the first European-based conversational AI platform vendor that owns its own speech technology,” concludes Stein. Europe needs to compete with large voice and conversational AI platform vendors abroad. “We’re on our way to becoming the leading voice and conversational AI platform for Europe.”

article.keywords: OmniBot, bot, AI, conversational AI platform, chatbot, NLP, virtual assistant, voice technology, speech technology

article.title: Terahertz innovation delivers ultra-high mobile data rates
article.teaser: Exponentially increasing demand for mobile data is placing huge demand on networks. EU-funded researchers have demonstrated that a bidirectional terahertz radio link could provide one solution.

section.sectionBody:
Since the advent of the smartphone, data consumption has exploded. Consumers and businesses increasingly rely on mobile data to deliver a range of services, and this demand is only expected to grow in the future.
“From a purely technical point of view, this presents a challenge,” notes https://thorproject.eu/ (ThoR) project coordinator Thomas Kürner from the https://www.tu-braunschweig.de/en/ (Technical University of Braunschweig) (TU Braunschweig) in Germany. “What can we do to facilitate higher data rates?”
One way is to increase the efficiency of data transmission systems, in order to squeeze more data into the bandwidth that is currently available. “This is getting more and more difficult to do,” says Kürner. Another way is to increase the bandwidth available. But this is challenging too, as more and more available spectrum gets used up.

The idea for the ThoR project came from the discovery that along the spectrum – beyond 275 gigahertz in the https://cordis.europa.eu/project/id/823878 (terahertz) (THz) frequency range – there is still bandwidth available to deliver mobile data services. “This space is not completely unregulated,” adds Kürner.
“There are some scientific applications like Earth-exploration satellites or radio astronomy that use bandwidth here. But enough available bandwidth has been found to potentially build systems that could deliver high data rates.”
To achieve this, a significant obstacle must be overcome. Using high frequencies can result in significant https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/engineering/path-loss (path loss), or a reduction in power intensity. To mitigate this loss, the potential of high-gain THz antennae to ensure a stable https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/backhaul (backhaul) link can be used.
The backhaul link of a mobile network describes the connection of a cell site – usually a cell tower – to the core network. While this link can be achieved via fibre-optic cables, this means digging up streets. In cities especially, connecting every base station of the mobile network by cable is simply not feasible.

The objective of the ThoR project therefore was to demonstrate that a THz radio relay link provided by antennae mounted on two rooftops could provide a viable alternative. The project team was confident that this would create a backhaul connection between mobile radio cells and the nodes of the mobile radio network, without the need for any road construction work.
To achieve this, the project brought together a consortium of partners from Europe and Japan. Many of these partners had developed the building blocks for such a prototype. The ThoR project took this work a step further by integrating these elements into a functional, bidirectional THz radio link.
Once the technology had been integrated, antennae were installed on two buildings on the university’s campus, at a distance of over 160 metres. Real data, including video, was then transmitted, and the efficacy of the system analysed by Kürner and his team.

The project successfully demonstrated the potential of a bidirectional THz radio link to the data network of mobile radio providers. The prototype was shown to be capable of transmitting very high data rates, and scalable so that even higher data rates could be realised.
“We were able to show how this technology can efficiently transport wireless communication,” says Kürner. “This could help ensure that all the capabilities that have been promised with https://cordis.europa.eu/project/id/856691 (5G) and 6G are realised.”
Further development of the prototype is still needed before the technology can be brought to market. Kürner and his team are nonetheless confident that the potential of this backhaul innovation is there.

article.keywords: ThoR, terahertz, mobile, radio, bandwidth, smartphone

article.title: Opening up Europe’s written cultural heritage to people all over the world
article.teaser: Millions of people will get the chance to access historical documents and gain insights into the aspects of history that appeal to them thanks to the READ project. The innovative approach to digitalisation makes handwritten documents from European archives accessible thanks to handwritten text recognition and keyword spotting.

section.sectionBody:
The READ project set out to implement a virtual research environment in which archivists, humanities scholars, computer scientists and volunteers could work together. The collective aim was the application of innovative technologies for the automated recognition, transcription and indexing of text to revolutionise access to historical documents.
“We wanted to be able to explore and access hundreds of kilometres of archival documents via handwritten text recognition and by doing so, open up one of the last hidden treasures of Europe’s rich cultural heritage,” explains project coordinator Günter Mühlberger, head of the https://www.uibk.ac.at/forschung/profilbildung/digital_humanities.html.en (Digital Humanities Research Centre) of the University of Innsbruck and a member of the https://www.timemachine.eu/ (Time Machine consortium). The project brought together several research groups and achieved scientific breakthroughs in fields such as handwritten text recognition, layout analysis and keyword spotting.
According to Mühlberger: “Along with these breakthroughs, we have set up the first, handwritten text recognition platform called https://transkribus.eu/Transkribus/ (Transkribus) where non-technical users can train their own networks to recognise specific scripts. More than 27 000 users are currently registered in the platform; hundreds of them use the platform daily.”
Mühlberger is delighted to see how well the platform is being received by people working in areas as diverse as natural language processing and medieval history, saying: “Transkribus represents the largest training dataset of historical handwriting worldwide. Based on this overwhelming success we have set up one of the first European Cooperative Societies in the research and cultural heritage domain.”

READ was based on several previous projects, mainly https://cordis.europa.eu/project/rcn/85383/factsheet/en (Improving Access to Text) and https://cordis.europa.eu/project/rcn/106843/factsheet/en (tranScriptorium) in which the basic research was carried out. “One of the most important success factors, however, was that the https://ec.europa.eu/digital-single-market/en/programme-and-projects/e-infrastructure-projects-factsheets (e-Infrastructure programme for Virtual Research Environments) gave us the chance to create a fully-fledged service,” Mühlberger adds.
But however much of a head-start previous projects gave the team, there were still challenges to resolve, as is ever the case! One such challenge was what Mühlberger refers to as ‘the layout analysis problem’. When it comes to handwritten text recognition, the first step in the processing pipeline is that the computer needs to know where there is actually text on a page. This might look like an easy task, but it was the hardest challenge at the beginning of the project.
“It was resolved by combining forces from several domains. First of all, a new concept of how to represent a line was introduced. Secondly, by far the largest dataset ever was created by integrating material from several archives. Finally, colleagues from the University of Rostock applied machine learning methods,” Mühlberger explains.
Their multi-pronged approach paid off. The result was that from about 85 % accuracy in finding lines on a handwritten page, the rate was increased to about 97 % accuracy.
The platform is gaining momentum. As Mühlberger says: “The National Archive in the Netherlands and the National Archives Finland started projects where millions of handwritten documents are made available via handwritten text recognition and keyword spotting to millions of users. These projects are among the first to be carried out with Transkribus and managed by the European Cooperative Society Transkribus.”

article.keywords: READ, archival documents, full-text search, Transkribus, digitalisation, handwritten text recognition

article.title: Satellites: A mini revolution unfolds above us
article.teaser: At the beginning of 2019, according to the United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs (UNOOSA), nearly 5 000 satellites were orbiting the Earth, an increase of 2.68 % on the previous year. Since the Soviet Union first launched Sputnik into orbit back in 1957, around 8 378 satellites have been sent up into outer space. Seven additional satellites are also orbiting planets other than Earth. However, not all of these nearly 5 000 satellites are still active – only around 2 000 are still functional, meaning that less than 40 % of the satellites currently in orbit are fully operational.
